definition: Structural components and elements that make up buildings and enclosed spaces

positive_examples: The contractor inspected the roof for damage after the storm
She walked through the doorway into the brightly lit room
The fireplace crackled warmly in the corner of the living room
Workers installed new ceiling tiles in the office building
The fence around the property marked the boundary clearly
Smoke rose from the brick chimney on a cold winter morning
negative_examples: The carpenter grabbed his hammer from the toolbox
The excavator dug a foundation hole for the new house
She planted flowers in the garden bed near the porch
The delivery truck parked in front of the warehouse
Construction materials were stacked on the building site
The architect drew blueprints for the proposed office complex
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: BuildingTools, Infrastructure, Furniture, Landscape, Vehicle

opposite_reasoning: NaturalLandFeatures provides the strongest semantic opposition for BuildingParts by capturing the human-made/natural dichotomy. While BuildingParts are manufactured structural components (walls, roofs, floors, chimneys), natural land features are geological formations shaped by natural processes (mountains, valleys, rivers, caves). This opposition is intuitive, mutually exclusive in origin, and maintains category coherence (both are physical spatial entities). It's more specific and meaningful than the abstract entity/process distinction, and more semantically rich than generic NaturalObject. For Fisher-LDA, this should create a clear axis separating artificial structures from natural formations.
